quotes.quote: The only thing aÂ titleÂ can buy is a little time-either to increase your level of influence with others or to undermine it.
It is a great deal of difference to receive an honorary title or a title in his profession.
Titles are too â€œthinâ€ for the nineteenth century.
The longer the title, the less important the job.
It is not titles that honor men, but men that honor titles.
Titles or organizational structures, that's not the lens through which we see our peers.
When youÂ titleÂ yourself, you immediately lend yourself to all kinds of pretension.
The three highest titles that can be given a man are those of martyr, hero, saint.
HighÂ titlesÂ debase, instead of elevate, those who know not how to support them.
A man's name,Â title, and rank are artificial and impermanent; they do nothing to reveal what he really is, even to himself.
Titles are but nicknames, and every nickname is a title.
TheÂ titleÂ is one of the most important things. It is the first thing that people read.
An abstractÂ titleÂ suggests another value to the subject, perhaps an artistic quality that sets the viewers' sensitivities into action.
Titles do not count with posterity.
A goodÂ titleÂ holds magic, some cognitive dissonance, a little grit between the teeth, but above all it is the jumping-off place into wonder.
No matter yourÂ title, people will not follow you if they don't trust you.
Titles distinguish the mediocre, embarrass the superior, and are disgraced by the inferior.
The wholeÂ titleÂ by which you possess your property, is not aÂ titleÂ of nature but of a human institution.
At the end of the day, the position is just a position, a title is just a title, and those things come and go. It's really your essence and your values that are important.
AnyÂ titles, money, or privilege you inherit are actually hindrances. They delude you into believing you are owed respect.
Titles are like a magicians wand which circumscribe human facility and prevent us from living the lives of man.
One of the greatestÂ titlesÂ in the world is parent, and one of the biggest blessings in the world is to have parents to call mom and dad.
If ourÂ titles recall the known myths of antiquity, we have used them again because they are the eternal symbols upon which we must fall back to express basic psychological ideas.
Titles have never given a just idea of things; were it otherwise, the work would be superfluous.
Being named among the best at something is special and beautiful. But if there are no titles, nothing is won.
Titles of honor are like the impressions on coins, which add no value to gold or silver, but only render brass current.
Titles are valuable; they make us acquainted with many persons who otherwise would be lost among the rubbish.
Titles are of no value to posterity; the name of a man who has achieved great deeds imposes more respect than any or all epithets.
Titles are marks of honest men, and wise; The fool or knave that wears aÂ titleÂ lies.
A goodÂ titleÂ should be like a good metaphor. It should intrigue without being too baffling or too obvious.
